Award.AbstractNarration:
In quantum mechanics, or in the microscopical physical world, an observable may be modeled by a self-adjoint operator on a Hilbert space. A system of such operators forms a C*-algebra. In the finite dimensional cases, these operators are just matrices. In more general cases, these operators may be represented by infinite matrices, or matrices on infinite dimensional Hilbert space. In the mathematical formulation of quantum mechanics, a pair of self-adjoint operators representing observables are typically non-commutative which corresponds to the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. The study of C*-algebra is often viewed as the study of non-commutative analogues of the algebra of continuous functions on a topological space. There are many C*-algebras that come from different fields of sciences and the study of C*-algebras has variety of applications. It is known that C*-algebras with different appearance from different applications can be the same. On the other hand, C*-algebras from the same source may look the same but have essentially different structure. For application purposes as well as the theoretical point of view, it is extremely important to determine the structure of C*-algebras from their appearance. This project is an attempt to use a small number of computable data to completely determine C*-algebras in certain classes. In other words one may study the computable data to understand the structure of C*-algebras.

This project is a study of classification of amenable C*-algebras using K-theory related invariants and applications of the classification. The main part of this project is to search for a broad classification of non-unital simple amenable C*-algebras. Part of the strategy is to create new technical tools to deal with non-commutative version of non-compact spaces. The goal is to establishe a new type of existence theorem as well as a K-theoretic characterization of asymptotic unitary equivalence for non-unital simple C*-algebras. A closely related topic is to verify certain C*-algebras satisfy the Universal Coefficient Theorem. The research of this project will also provide a new passage to greatly simplify the way in which the theory of C*-algebras is applied to various other related research areas, notably, to non-commutative homotopy theory and the study of dynamical systems. For example, it is proposed, using this broad classification theory, to study a new relation among minimal homeomorphisms on a compact metric space which is called asymptotic conjugacy, and ultimately characterize this relation via K-theoretical data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes report

General description: This project is a study of the structure of simple C*-algebras. A C*- algebra is an algebraic system of some infinite matrices. C*-algebras may also arise from many mathematical fields such as dynamical systems and group representations. The main goal of the project is to use a set of K-theoretical data to determine the structure of simple C*-algebras from different sources. The outcomes of the project include certain general description of the properties of a model class of separable simple C*-algebras, a classification theorem for a board class of separable simple amenable C*-algebras via their K-theoretical data. More specifically, the classification theorem states, with a regular condition, all separable simple C*-algebras in the class are isomorphic to one of the models, and a set of K-theoretical data determines which specific model a given C*-algebra in the class is isomorphic to. Outcomes also include a proof that C*-algebras arisen from minimal dynamical systems on a finite dimensional metric space are in the classifiable class and are determined by their K-theoretical data.

Intellectual merit As a first outcome of this project, it was found that the transformation C*-algebra given by a minimal homeomorphism on a finite dimensional metric space is in the classifiable class of C*-algebras and therefore the C*-algebra structure as well as some dynamical structure can be determined by its K-theory and invariant measures. In the first paper in a sequence of classification results, it introduces a class of simple C*-algebras of generalized tracial rank at most one for non-unital C*-algebras. It is shown that the C*-algebras in the class have many nice and important regularity properties such as the strict comparison and stable rank one. In the amenable case, these simple C*-algebras also have finite nuclear dimension. In the second published paper in the sequence, the class of KK-contractible of separable simple C*-algebras of finite nuclear dimension is studied. It is shown that these C*-algebras have generalized tracial rank at most one. An isomorphism theorem is established. These C*-algebras are completely determined by their tracial data. In the third paper in the sequence, a much broader class of separable simple C*-algebras are classified by their K-theoretical data. It found that there is a unique separable simple C*-algebra which can be absorbed by any simple C*-algebra in the broad class of separable simple C*-algebras and any separable simple C*-algebra tensoring it is in the class. Moreover, specific models for each possible K-theoretical data are constructed. The methods developed in these research have potential applications in other research topics and open the way for the further understanding of the structure of simple C*-algebras.

Broader impacts This project helps to introduce operator algebras to more people in the scientific world. A CBMS (Conference Board of the Mathematical Sciences) lecture notes contains closely related results were published. During the support of the project, the PI was the main organizer of 2018 International Workshop on Operator Theory and Applications with over 350 participants from 34 countries. All findings of this project have been presented in conferences and workshops such as Mathematical Congress of the Americas, The Fields Institute, The Banff Research Station, The Research Center for Operator Algebras and Oberwolfach Mathematical Research Center. A number of Postdocs and Ph.D. students around the world show their interests and are engaging the research which is closely related to this project. The results in the structure theory of C*-algebras have been known to have important applications in operator theory, linear algebras as well as classical dynamical systems. It has also been established that the further understanding of the structure of separable C*-algebras will have applications in abstract harmonic analysis, geometry and non-commutative geometry as well as topology. In a long run and via other researches, this project may find applications in group representations, model quantum field theory and quantum statistical mechanics.
